samples.text: A simple coin toss does not appear as it would on Earth.
Dropping the coin causes it to curve the other way.
A drop in low gravity looks exactly the same, but slower
Dropped from almost (not quite) the center of the station, as if from a tall ladder
Dropping it from the exact center of the station causes it to never land.
A toss at this angle causes it to loop back on itself
At this angle it comes to a point instead of the parabola you would see on Earth.
Throwing it opposite the rotation counteracts the gravity and causes it to stretch out.
If you match the rotation speed almost exactly, the object will spin in the air perpetually.
Changing the throw angle by a degree causes it to spiral upwards.
If you throw it fast enough, it will hit the ceiling.
The space station would have to be enourmous to make the distortion imperceptible.
By launching a high-speed object on a huge station, you still see unexpected shapes.
Launching straight up at high speed, the object would land several kilometers away (fast playback speed).
Playing with artificial gravity can be fun!
